Colin Green wrote:

>[...]
>
>Another major point I want to make is that performance is largely a 
>function of the code, not what language it is written in. Sloppy C++ 
>will run slower than well written C#. Also consider the neural network 
>code optimizations I worked on recently, the code was clear, well 
>written and (I thought) nice tight optimal code - which it was. But I 
>was able to achieve an 8x speed increase by considering Ian Badcoes 
>suggestions about CPU caches and re-ordering the sequence of execution.
>
err, it just occurred to me that this might be interpreted as a slur on 
WindowsNEAT (or other NEAT implementations), which of course it was not! 
It's a general observation mostly derived from observations in the 
commercial world where quality, clarity, maintainability, etc are not 
always the main goals, often resulting in 'rats nest' type code that is 
completely unfathomable!

Colin.
